awd_titl_txt: CAREER: High-Performance Packet Processing with Programmable NIC Data-Planes
awd_abstract_narration:
In today's data centers, network performance is surging, outstripping
the capacity of modern processors, and turning them into a performance
bottleneck for demanding data center applications. Examples of
applications suffering from this problem include the back end services
implementing Facebook, Google, Amazon, and other popular
websites. These services spend most of their time conducting network
input/output. As the gap between processor and network performance widens,
these services become less and less efficient. More efficient server
software can ameliorate the situation, increasing the performance of
applications while also reducing a data center's prodigious energy
consumption.

This project investigates a re-design of the server hardware and
software network stack, with the aim to streamline and improve network
I/O energy-efficiency. To do so, the project utilizes a new
programming model for energy-efficient packet processing in network
cards, called match-and-action processing. The approach allows
applications and operating systems to install packet processing rules
to the network card that instruct it to execute simple operations on
packets while transferring them to and from the host. This model is
highly energy efficient, yet allows to retain network protocol
implementation flexibility and compatibility with existing
applications.

The work has the potential for dramatic improvements in application
and server performance, as well as data center energy
consumption. Network intensive data center applications are used by
billions of people around the globe on a daily basis. By reducing the
overhead of networking, the hardware needed to support existing
services can be reduced, making it cheaper for new services to be
developed.

To evaluate the space of design alternatives, the project builds a
working prototype and an emulator capable of running standard server
applications. All source code, along with configuration files and
instructions for reproducing published measurements of the system,
will be made public and accessible from the project website at UT
Austin (http://www.cs.utexas.edu/~simon/flexnic). The website will be
actively maintained for the duration of the project.

por.por_cntn:
The project significantly advanced the field of networked systems through the development and implementation of the FlexNIC design, aimed to revolutionize packet processing in data centers by leveraging programmable network interface cards (SmartNICs) to improve performance and efficiency. The project achieved its goals by successfully implementing a stream-based FlexNIC design in software-based emulation and developing a prototype on fully programmable NIC hardware. This foundational work resulted in a software-based TCP acceleration service (TAS) that significantly improved throughput and latency for common cloud applications, showcasing throughput improvements of up to 4.3x and latency reductions of up to 7.3x compared to traditional Linux stacks. The NIC prototype, called FlexTOE, builds on TAS's foundation by exploiting the programmability and flexibility of SmartNICs to further enhance TCP processing efficiency. By offloading more complex TCP stack operations to SmartNICs, FlexTOE reduces the processing load on the host CPU, leading to improved performance and efficiency for networked applications. This advancement demonstrates the potential of programmable network hardware in accelerating and optimizing network functions.

The project also explored the application of FlexNICs in various contexts, including remote direct memory access and microservices, and investigated the integration of virtual machine monitors and operating systems. These efforts highlighted the challenges and opportunities in offloading tasks to SmartNICs, leading to collaborations aimed at simplifying software development for these devices, including platforms that aid offload of application-level tasks to SmartNICs. The team also developed a system providing mechanisms for fast and efficient data plane operations within virtual machines, reducing the performance overhead typically associated with virtualization technologies. Another developed system focuses on minimizing the overhead associated with movement of I/O data within applications and between I/O stacks. It introduces mechanisms to achieve zero-copy data transfers, significantly enhancing the efficiency of I/O operations, particularly in high-speed networking systems. 

Dissemination of results to the broader scientific community and industry stakeholders was accomplished through more than 8 publications, conference presentations, and seminars. Further significant outcomes included the development of teaching materials and the facilitation of training and professional development opportunities. The project supported the graduation of PhD students and the involvement of undergraduate students in honors thesis projects related to FlexNIC, thereby contributing to the education and development of future researchers in the field. In terms of societal impact, the project's advancements in data center energy efficiency are expected to contribute positively to environmental sustainability by reducing the energy consumption of data center servers.

Overall, the project demonstrated significant achievements in networked systems research, offering solutions for packet processing that promise to influence both academic research and industry practice. The successful completion of this project underscores the potential of programmable NICs to transform data center operations, highlighting the importance of continued research and development in this field.
